â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•
Market Summary
ãƒ»BTC is hovering around the 92Kâ€“94K range, with a â€œquiet preâ€“relief rallyâ€ structure that clearly points to upside resistance levels at 99K â†’ 102K â†’ 112K.
ãƒ»ETH has firmly broken above 3,400 dollars, supported by demand recovery, shrinking exchange balances, and anticipation around the Fusaka upgrade â€“ a classic â€œflow-driven breakout.â€
ãƒ»Stablecoin market cap continues to rise above 300B dollars, building a thick pool of â€œdry powderâ€ that can quickly ignite risk assets once demand returns.
ãƒ»The Fed delivered a 25 bp rate cut as expected and announced 40B dollars in T-bill purchases over the next 30 days, clearly shifting the short-term liquidity environment in favor of risk assets.
ãƒ»However, the dots and Powellâ€™s tone remain â€œdovish but cautious,â€ creating the classic â€œhawkish cutâ€ setup where volatility often spikes after the event.
ãƒ»Gold and silver are still among the best YTD performers, while BTC and ETH remain laggards versus both precious metals and major equity indices â€“ reinforcing the idea that crypto is a â€œlate-cycle risk assetâ€ with catch-up potential.
â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•
On-Chain & Technical Trends
ãƒ»Total BTC reserves on exchanges have dropped from about 2.97M to 2.76M BTC over the last three months â€“ a historic low in tradable supply and a sign of ongoing accumulation into long-term wallets.
ãƒ»On the other hand, Binance has seen highly volatile flows: a sharp BTC inflow in November followed by sizable outflows in December. Big players moving in and out still have outsized impact on price.
ãƒ»BTC has been rising while open interest continues to decline â€“ a â€œspot-driven rally.â€ Leverage is relatively light and structurally healthier than at the April bottom, but sustained upside will eventually require OI to trend higher again.
ãƒ»ETH whales have accumulated roughly 934K ETH in recent weeks while exchange balances approach their lowest levels since Ethereumâ€™s early years â€“ a textbook â€œpre-supply-shockâ€ setup.
ãƒ»Spot volume has increased compared to the April bottom, while futures volume is more muted, pointing to â€œless casino, more value-driven flowsâ€ â€“ a constructive sign for medium- to long-term structure.
ãƒ»Technically, BTCâ€™s RSI has still not reached classical oversold â€œmajor bottomâ€ levels, meaning a definitive bottom signal is not yet in place. ETHâ€™s surge looks driven by a combination of short covering and fresh longs, so chasing too aggressively carries overshoot risk.
â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•
Sentiment
ãƒ»After the FOMC cut, short-term sentiment is split between â€œrelief that the event is overâ€ and â€œconcern about the dots and macro outlook,â€ creating a polarized mood.
ãƒ»CryptoQuant-style analyses highlight falling selling pressure and ongoing capitulation, leading more participants to argue that itâ€™s time to begin phased spot accumulation.
ãƒ»ETH whale buying and the increase in stablecoin supply are widely seen as â€œpre-risk-on positioning,â€ while the lack of a clear oversold signal and macro uncertainty keep the cautious camp alive.
ãƒ»Strongly supportive comments from Cantor Fitzgerald and other traditional players, plus JPMorganâ€™s year-end rally call, are helping underpin risk appetite.
ãƒ»At the same time, GameStopâ€™s 9.4M-dollar loss on BTC holdings is a reminder that unmanaged crypto exposure can directly hit earnings, keeping â€œreckless bullishnessâ€ out of favor.
ãƒ»Overall, the dominant mood is â€œcautious optimismâ€ â€“ many feel we may be at the early stage of a new bull phase, but that itâ€™s still too soon to go all-in.
â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•
U.S. Traditional Markets
ãƒ»The Fed delivered a 25 bp rate cut while signaling a limited number of cuts next year. Markets are now more focused on the economic and inflation outlook than on the cut itself.
ãƒ»The OCC has opened the door for U.S. banks to act as intermediaries for crypto transactions, effectively enabling a â€œbank front / crypto back-endâ€ model and accelerating the integration of BTC and ETH into existing wealth-management channels.
ãƒ»Gold remains in the spotlight, with Goldman Sachs projecting 4,900 dollars by the end of 2026, reinforcing the broader rotation into safe assets, while crypto sits on the outer rim as a higher-beta satellite allocation.
ãƒ»JPMorgan expects risk-on conditions to persist into year-end, with the strength in public credit markets potentially spilling over into equities and crypto.
ãƒ»Geopolitically, rising tensions in East Asia â€“ including the U.S. explicitly backing Japan against recent Chinese military actions â€“ add a non-negligible tail risk of sudden risk-off shocks triggered by headlines.
â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•
Overall Assessment
The market has shifted from a phase where â€œhealthy structure vs. macro riskâ€ were evenly balanced to one that is now leaning slightly in favor of the bulls. ETHâ€™s breakout above 3,400 dollars, aggressive whale accumulation, rising stablecoin supply, shrinking BTC exchange reserves, and U.S. banks being allowed to intermediate crypto all point to a structurally improving backdrop over the next 1â€“3 months.
At the same time, classic post-FOMC â€œbuy the rumor, sell the newsâ€ volatility, the absence of a textbook oversold bottom signal on BTC, and rising geopolitical tension mean short-term shock risk is still very real. Todayâ€™s XWIN TREND INDEX prints 72 / 100, with a directional bias of â€œmild uptrend.â€
Looking one month ahead, the most reasonable stance is to focus on â€œphased spot accumulation with light leverage,â€ and to avoid over-trading the noise in the days immediately following the FOMC â€“ positioning and risk management matter more than trying to perfectly predict the next headline move.
